content.description:
Directions: Read the following selection carefully for comprehension. The selection is followed by a number of related questions and incomplete statements. Select the best answer or completion.

Catullus laments a tragic event. 

In this passage, Catullus compares his youthful pleasures with his present sorrow at his brother's death.

Tempore quo primum vestis mihi tradita pura est,

iucundum cum aetas ﬂorida ver ageret,

multa satis lusi: non est dea nescia nostri,

quae dulcem curis miscet amaritiem.1

(5) Sed totum hoe studium luctu fraterna mihi mors

abstulit. O misero frater adempte mihi,

tu mea tu moriens fregisti commoda, frater,

tecum una tota est nostra sepulta domus,

omnia tecum una perierunt gaudia nostra,

quae tuus in vita dulcis alebat amor.

1 amarities, -ei, f.: bitterness
content.question: Line 2 (iucundum . . . ageret) is translated literally

choices.label: when my pleasant age had led a flowery springtime
although the pleasant springtime had driven away the ﬂowers
when my ﬂourishing lifetime was having a pleasant springtime
since the pleasant springtime was driven to a flowery youth

content.answer: when my ﬂourishing lifetime was having a pleasant springtime

unit.text: 4: Teacher's Choice - Latin Poetry and Vergil's Aeneid, Excerpts from Books 1 and 2
